review.title: Q-WordNet PPV: Simple, Robust and (almost) Unsupervised Generation of Polarity Lexicons for Multiple Languages
review.abstract: This paper presents a simple, robust and (almost) unsupervised dictionary-based method, qwn-ppv (Q-WordNet as Personalized PageRanking Vector) to automatically generate polarity lexicons. We show that qwn-ppv outperforms other automatically generated lexicons for the four extrinsic evaluations presented here. It also shows very competitive and robust results with respect to manually annotated ones. Results suggest that no single lexicon is best for every task and dataset and that the intrinsic evaluation of polarity lexicons is not a good performance indicator on a Sentiment Analysis task. The qwn-ppv method allows to easily create quality polarity lexicons whenever no domain-based annotated corpora are available for a given language.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: Previous approaches provided an intrinsic evaluation (Mohammad et al., 2009; Rao and Ravichandran, 2009; Baccianella et al., 2010) using manually commented resources such as the General Inquirer (Stone et al., 1966) as the gold standard. To facilitate comparison, we also offer such a evaluation in Section 4.3. Nevertheless, and as the results of the extrinsic evaluations show, we believe that polarity lexicon should generally be evaluated extrinsically. Finally, each polarity lexicon is as good as the results obtained by using it for a specific sentiment analysis task. sections.heading: 5 Concluding Remarks
sections.text: Although this method is simpler than similar automatic approaches, it still achieves better results based on the four extrinsic ratings presented. As it depends only on the availability of an LKB, we believe that this method can be valuable in generating polarity dictionaries for a particular language on demand if there is insufficient commented data available. We demonstrate the adaptability of our approach by creating good performance polarity dictionaries for different assessment scenarios and for more than one language. Further work includes investigating various graph projections of WordNet relationships for propagation, as well as using synset weights. We also plan to examine the use of commented corpora to generate lexicon at the word level to try to close the gap with those that have been commented (at least in part) manually. The qwn-ppv dictionaries and charts used in this paper are available at qwn-ppv (http: / pplev).
